Indications: Mediastinal adenopathy
Procedure: EBUS bronchoscopy
Medications: General Anesthesia
Procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives were explained to the patient. All questions were answered and informed consent was documented as per institutional protocol. A history and physical were performed and updated in the pre-procedure assessment record. Laboratory studies and radiographs were reviewed. A time-out was performed prior to the intervention.
Following intravenous medications as per the record and topical anesthesia to the upper airway and tracheobronchial tree, the Q190 video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. The laryngeal mask airway was in good position. The vocal cords appeared normal. The subglottic space was normal. The trachea was of normal caliber. The carina was sharp. The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level. Bronchial mucosa and anatomy were normal; there are no endobronchial lesions, and no secretions. The video bronchoscope was then removed and the UC180F convex probe EBUS bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. A large, station 4R, lymph node was id[REDACTED] and sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed with the Olympus 19G Visioshot EBUS-TBNA needles with a total of 7 passes performed. Initial rapid onsite evaluation showed scattered lymphocytes but no evidence of malignancy or granuloma. We then placed the Olympus mini-forceps through the working channel of the EBUS scope and adnaved the forceps through a tract in the airway created by the EBUS needle. We were able to visualize the forceps using the EBUS ultrasound within the lymph node. We then closed and retracted the forceps. This was performed twice and touchpreps were made with the collected specimins which showed abundant non-caseating granulomas on rapid onsite pathological evaluation. Following completion of EBUS bronchoscopy, the Q190 video bronchoscope was then re-inserted and after suctioning blood and secretions there was no evidence of active bleeding and the bronchoscope was subsequently removed. 

Complications: No immediate complications
Estimated Blood Loss: 5cc
Post Procedure Diagnosis:
- Technically successful flexible bronchoscopy with endobronchial ultrasound-guided needle and mini-forceps.
- The patient has remained stable and has been transferred in good condition to the post-procedural monitoring unit.
- Will await final pathology results

Indications: Pulmonary nodule requiring diagnosis/staging. 
Medications: Propofol infusion via anesthesia assistance  
Procedure, risks, benefits, and alternatives were explained to the patient. All questions were answered and informed consent was documented as per institutional protocol. A history and physical were performed and updated in the preprocedure assessment record. Laboratory studies and radiographs were reviewed. A time-out was performed prior to the intervention. 
Following intravenous medications as per the anesthesia record and topical anesthesia to the upper airway and tracheobronchial tree the Q190 video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth. The vocal cords appeared normal. The subglottic space was normal. The trachea is of normal caliber. The carina was sharp. All left and right sided airways were normal without endobronchial disease to the first segmental branch. The video bronchoscope was then removed and the UC180F convex probe EBUS bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. A systematic hilar and mediastinal lymph node survey was carried out. Sampling criteria (5mm short axis diameter) were met in station 11L, station 7, 10R 11Rs lymph nodes.  Sampling by transbronchial needle aspiration was performed in these lymph nodes using an Olympus EBUSTBNA 22 gauge needle beginning at the N3 (11L) lymph nodes 711Rs10R. Further details regarding nodal size and number of samples are included in the attached EBUS procedural sheet. All samples were sent for routine cytology. Onsite path eval did not id[REDACTED] malignancy. We then removed the EBUS bronchoscopy and the ultrathin bronchoscope was inserted and based on anatomical knowledge advanced into the right middle lobe to the area of known nodule using radial EBUS confirmed a concentric view within the lesion. Biopsies were then performed with a variety of instruments to include peripheral needle, forceps and brush. After adequate samples were obtained the bronchoscope was removed. While emerging from anesthesia patient had large volume emesis and possible aspiration event. He was immediately placed on right side. He transiently became hypoxic but saturations improved relatively quickly. Patinet was then transferred to the PACU. X-ray was performed which right greater than left patchy opacities with increased pulmonary vasculature and interstitial markings alone with a small right apical pneumothorax. Right sided airspace opacities, although possibly representing aspiration event, are more likely related to retained saline instilled during bronchoscopy and is not unexpected. Patient was informed of pneumothorax. He was hemodynamically stable and oxygenating well. Repeat CXR 1 hour later showed no expansion of pneumothorax and decision was made to observe for expansion and not place chest tube unless he develops symptoms or has expansion of pneumothorax.

Complications: 
1.	Small left apical pneumothorax
2.	Post procedure emesis with possible aspiration  
Estimated Blood Loss: Less than 10 cc.
Recommendations:
- Admit to IM for overnight observation
- Repeat CXR in 4 hours and then AM if not changes
- Consider diuresis given pulmonary edema and Systolic heart failure
- Continue to hold Plavix for now.
- Would NOT treat with antibiotics 
- Await final pathology

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  Right lower lobe segmental obstruction 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSES:
1.	Mucous plugging, with diffuse tracheobronchitis. 
2.	Mild Trachobronchiomlalacia 

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:  flexible bronchoscopy with bronchial washing
CONSCIOUS SEDATION:
1.  Fentanyl 100 mg IV push.
2.  Versed 4 mg IV push.

TOPICAL ANESTHESIA:  29 cc 1% lidocaine 

SPECIMENS SENT:

1.  Bronchial washing sent for cytology and culture
FINDINGS:  
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE:  After appropriate consent was obtained from the patient, all risks and benefits were explained to him.  The patient was brought to the endoscopy suite and administered local anesthesia to the left naris and posterior pharynx.  This was then followed by administration of conscious sedation. The Olympus Q190 bronchoscope was then inserted through the left nare into the posterior oropharynx.   The vocal cords appeared to move normally during pronation. The bronchoscope was then passed into the trachea. Tthere appeared to be mild tracheomalacia as well as diffuse tracheobronchitis with boggy erythematous mucous extending throughout the right and left bronchial trees with thick yellow mucous seen throughout the airways. After suctioning of mucous plugs inspection was performed to at least the first subsegmental bronchi on all left and right sided airways. No endobronchial lesions were id[REDACTED]. The bronchoscope was then advanced to the right lower lobe and the bronchoscope was wedged into the lateral segment.  Bronchoalveolar lavage was then performed at this segment utilizing 90 mL of saline. The wedge was lost due to coughing and suction was reapplied yielding a bronchial wash rather than a true BAL. When this was completed, the airways were again inspected and no evidence of hemorrhage was seen.  The bronchoscope was withdrawn.  The patient tolerated the procedure well.  There were no complications.

 Recommendations:
1.	Await cytology and culture results.
2.	Repeat CT chest in 1 month to ensure resolution of radiographic findings.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Endotracheal tumor 
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS:  Endotracheal tumor s/p debulking 
INDICATIONS: Tracheal Obstruction  
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. After administration of sedatives and paralytics the flexible bronchoscope was inserted through the LMA and into the pharynx. We then advanced the bronchoscope into the subglottic space. The subglottic area and proximal trachea were normal. At the level of the med trachea there was a large polypoid tumor with a ball valve effect with the base at the left posterior tracheal wall. The tumor was about 90% obstructive of the normal tracheal diameter. Additionally there wer multiple small polypoid lesions surrounding the large obstructive mass mostly on the posterior wall of the trachea but also on the anterior and right tracheal wall. These findings extended for about 3cm. We did not attempt to pass the polypoid lesion with the bronchoscope during the initial inspection.  The flexible bronchoscope and LMA were removed and a 10mm non-ventilating rigid tracheoscope was subsequently inserted into the mid trachea just proximal to the tumor and connected to ventilator. The T190 Olympus flexible bronchoscope was then introduced through the rigid bronchoscope and the electrocautery snare was used to transect the obstructive mass at its base. We then inserted the 1.9mm cryotherapy probe through the flexible bronchoscope and attached the probe using cryotherapy to the resected tumor and attempted to extract it through the rigid bronchoscope. The tumor however was too large and repeatedly fell off of the cryoprobe when trying to pull it through the rigid scope. We then switched to the large 2.4mm cryoprobe and again using the same technique were able to pull pieces of the tumor out if a piecemeal fashion and residual pieces of the resected tumor were then extracted with flexible forceps. After the primary tumor was removed we then used APC to paint and shave the remaining tumor area on the posterior and lateral trachea walls until we were satisfied that we had achieved adequate luminal recanalization. At the end of the procedure the trachea was approximately 95% open in comparison to unaffected areas. We then were able to complete the distal airway inspection. The lower trachea, right sided and left sided airways to at least the first sub-segments were uninvolved with no evidence of endobronchial tumor or extrinsic obstruction. The rigid bronchoscope was then removed, and the procedure was completed. There were no complications.
Recommendations:
           Transfer patient back to ICU 
           Obtain post procedure CXR
           Await final pathology results

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Esophageal cancer
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Esophageal cancer with TR fistula and endobronchial invasion. 
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Rigid bronchoscopy, endobronchial biopsy, tumor debulking, and Silicone Y-stent placement
INDICATIONS: Extrinsic airway compression and suspected TE fistula.
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. All questions were answered and informed consent was documented as per institutional protocol. A history and physical were performed and updated in the pre-procedure assessment record. Laboratory studies and radiographs were reviewed. A time-out was performed prior to the intervention.
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the bronchoscopy suite. Following intravenous medications as per the record a laryngeal mask airway was inserted. Topical anesthesia was then applied to the upper airway and the T190 video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. The laryngeal mask airway was in good position. The right vocal cord was irregular appearing with small vocal cord nodule visualized.  The subglottic space was normal. The trachea was normal with the exception of some mild mucosal irregularity in distal 2cm of the posterior tracheal wall. Thick purulent material was seen pulling at the level of the carina and the proximal left mainstem. After clearing secretions a endobronchial mass which appeared to extend from the esophagus was visualized within the proximal left mainstem causing about 80% endobronchial obstruction.  Just proximal to that mass was a small area where GI contents could be seen entering the airway consistent with a small TE fistula.  This was only about 1-2 mm distal to the main carina.  After bypassing the main tumor within the proximal left mainstem which was about 1 cm in depth submucosal infiltration could be seen for approximately 4 cm within the left mainstem bronchi.  There were purulent thick secretions throughout the left-sided airways which were suctioned via trap and sent for culture.  The right mainstem was significantly obstructed (approximately 70%) extrinsically with the greatest degree obstruction just proximal to the right upper lobe takeoff.  The bronchus intermedius appeared uninvolved and was widely patent.  The right middle lobe was normal to at least the first subsegmental bronchi.  In the proximal aspect of the right lower lobe was some black discoloration of the mucosa but did not appear to be malignant and there is no endobronchial disease or obstruction to at least the first subsegmental bronchi.  
Following inspection the flexible bronchoscope and LMA were removed and a 12mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was subsequently inserted into the upper trachea and advanced to the distal trachea and connected to the Jet ventilator.  The T190 Olympus flexible bronchoscope was then introduced through the rigid bronchoscope and into the airways. Forcep biopsies were taken of the proximal left mainstem mass.  Moderate bleeding was encountered which was treated with topical epinephrine.  After adequate samples were taken APC was used to burn and shave the lesion using the tip of the bronchoscope to remove the devascularized tissue as well as forceps to remove associated debris.  After debulking the left mainstem was approximately 90% patent throughout.  Due to the carinal involvement with fistulization as well as the right mainstem extrinsic obstruction decision was made to place a silicone Y stent into the airway. Measurements of the airway were then taken in anticipation of airway stent placement. We customized a 14x10x10 silicone Y-stent to a length of 40mm in the tracheal limb, 25mm in the right mainstem limb and 45mm in the left mainstem limb.  The rigid bronchoscope was then removed and we initially attempted to insert the stent using Freitag forceps with indirect laryngoscopy.  This was unsuccessful and at one point the stent was deployed within the proximal esophagus.  The LMA was removed at that point and an endotracheal tube inserted after which we navigated into the proximal esophagus with the flexible bronchoscope, id[REDACTED] the stent and removed with flexible forceps.  After aborting attempts at Freitag placement a 14 mm rigid bronchoscope was inserted into the airway for dimensional stent deployment.  The Rigid bronchoscope was then advanced to the proximal right mainstem and the stent was deployed. After deployment, the rigid forceps were used to manipulate the stent to adequately position the limbs within the proper airways resulting in successful stabilization of the airway. The rigid bronchoscope was removed and an LMA was inserted. The flexible bronchoscope was then inserted through the LMA for re-inspection. The Stent was well seated. The trachea and left mainstem were widely patent and the area of disease mucosa within the left mainstem was completely covered.  The right mainstem only improved in diameter to approximately 50% of normal due to continued extrinsic compression on the stent from her esophageal mass. The bronchoscope was subsequently removed and the procedure completed.  After removal of the bronchoscope it was noted that the patient had a small laceration on her tongue which developed during the procedure.
Complications: Small tongue laceration
Estimated blood loss: 10 cc
Recommendations:
- Transfer PACU
- Obtain post procedure CXR
- ENT consult to evaluate tongue laceration
- Patient will transfer back to the VA once PACU discharge criteria are met.  
- Nebulized hypertonic (3%) saline 3 cc mixed with 2 cc of albuterol TID for stent maintenance and clearance of secretions.  Patient will need to have a home nebulizer arranged prior to discharge to home.
- Patient to follow-up in the interventional pulmonary clinic in one month or earlier if any issues develop which require earlier evaluation.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Lung cancer with tumor obstruction of bronchus intermedius
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Malignant intrinsic airway obstruction
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Rigid bronchoscopy with endobronchial dubulking
INDICATIONS: Tumor obstruction of bronchus intermedius  
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. Following induction and paralyitic administration by anesthesia a 11 mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was inserted into the mid trachea and attached to the ventilator. The rigid optic was then removed and the flexible bronchoscope was inserted through the rigid bronchoscope. On initial bronchoscopic inspection the trachea, left lung and right upper lobe appeared normal without evidence of endobronchial disease. In the orifice of the right upper lobe there was mucosal tumor infiltration causing partial (about 30% obstruction of the lobe). Just distal to the right upper lobe orifice in the bronchus intermedius there was a large polypoid tumor with base on the lateral wall causing complete airway obstruction.  At this point the flexible forceps were used to take tissue samples for pathological evaluation.  We then attempted to secure the polypoid lesion using the electrocautery snare however were unable to get the snare to wrap around the distal aspect and this was subsequently aborted. We then used the ND-YAG  began to slowly devascularize. After which the rigid optic was reinserted and the rigid bronchoscope was advanced to the level of the lesion and using an apple coring technique with the bevel of the rigid bronchoscope we were able to cut through stock of the lesion. We then reinserted the flexible bronchoscope and using suction were able to secure the free lesion and remove en-block with suction. After this the airway was essentially open however there was significant residual mucosal tumor at the base and extending to the level of the basilar branches of the right lower lobe obstructing both the middle lobe and superior segment of the right lower lobe. The middle lobe and superior segment were found and opened to approximately 50% of normal diameter.  APC was used to debulk the residual tumor using a burn and shave technique as well as flexible forceps to remove coagulated debris. We were able to achieve approximately 85% recanalization of the proximal bronchus intermedius, and 60% of the distal BI. A similar technique was then used to remove the mucosal infiltrating tumor at the orifice of the right upper lobe with end result approximately 80% recanalization. Placement of a stent to prevent re-ingrowth was considered however based on the patients wishes (to avoid stent unless absolutely necessary) as well as the need to likely jail the right middle lobe and superior segment with the stent we decided to forgo this intervention and see how patient responds both clinically and to any possible systemic therapy which might prevent recurrence. Once we were satisfied that there was no active bleeding the rigid bronchoscope was removed and the procedure was completed. 
Recommendations:
Await tissue diagnosis for confirmation of recurrence 
Obtain CXR in PACU.
We expect the obstruction to recur without systemic treatment and possibly radiation due to the extent of tumor involvement. Will discuss with patients primary oncologist regarding options for systemic therapy.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Lung mass with left main-stem obstruction
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Malignant mixed intrinsic and extrinsic airway obstruction
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Rigid bronchoscopy
INDICATIONS: left mainstem obstruction 
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. A 7.0 ETT was placed by ansesthesia followed by OG tube to decompress the stomach. The ETT was then removed and a 12 mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was subsequently inserted into the mid trachea and attached to the jet ventilator. The rigid optic was then removed and the flexible bronchoscope was inserted through the rigid bronchoscope. On initial bronchoscopic inspection there was mild bleeding and airway trauma noted in the distal trachea likely secondary to trauma from ETT placement. The posterior and left wall of the distal trachea had obvious submucosal tumor infiltration. The left mainstem bronchus was completely obstructed by endoluminal tumor and the tumor involved the main carina with a mild degree of tumor ingrowth into the right mainstem but without obstruction. At this point the EBUS bronchoscope was inserted through the rigid bronchoscope and the subcarinal mass was id[REDACTED] with ultrasound and 6 biopsies were performed with the 22G EBUS TBNA needle. We then directed our attention to the left maintem. Through the use of a combination of APC, rigid electrocautery, cryotherapy and forcpts we were able to slowly debulk the tumor within the left mainstem and visualize an opening into the distal left mainstem. A ultrathin bronchospe was advanced through the opening and purulent material was expressed from the distal airways from her post-obstructive pneumonia. We were able to visualize the secondary carinas within the left upper lobe and there was no obvious tumor seen. The left lower lobe was visualized but we were unable to adequately debulk the tumor to overlying this area to confirm distal patency. Subseuqently the left mainstem bronchus was dilated with an [REDACTED] CRE balloon with approximaly 50% improvement in luminal patency in the left mainstem which allowed introduction of the therapeutic bronchoscope. At this point the infiltrating friable areas of tumor within the left mainstem, distal trachea and main carina were painted with argon plasma coagulation for hemostasis. Once we were satisfied that there was no active bleeding the rigid bronchoscope was removed and the procedure was completed. 
Recommendations:
Await tissue diagnosis
ASAP radiation oncology consultation for treatment of the left mainstem to attempt to prevent recurrent obstruction.
If patient develops significant hemoptysis post procedure would perform bronchoscopic intubation of the right mainstem to protect functional lung. 
If obstruction recurs despite radiation therapy will likely require repeat rigid bronchoscopy with placement of silicone Y stent.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Malignant lung mass with left lower lobe and partial left main-stem obstruction
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Malignant airway obstruction 
INDICATIONS: left mainstem obstruction 
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. Following intravenous medications as per the record and topical anesthesia to the upper airway and tracheobronchial tree, the T180 therapeutic video bronchoscope was introduced through the mouth, via laryngeal mask airway and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. The laryngeal mask airway was in good position. The vocal cords appeared normal. The subglottic space was normal. The trachea was of normal caliber. The carina was sharp. The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level. Right sided bronchial mucosa and anatomy were normal; there are no endobronchial lesions, and no secretions.  The proximal and mid left mainstem were normal. In the distal left mainstem a white fungating tumor was seen causing complete obstruction of the left lower lobe and extending from the left lower lobe bronchus to causing complete obstruction of the lingula and 80% obstruction of the left mainstem.  The LMA was then removed and a 12 mm ventilating rigid bronchoscope was subsequently inserted into the mid trachea and attached to the jet ventilator. The rigid optic was then removed and the flexible bronchoscope was inserted through the rigid bronchoscope. We then utilized cryoextraction to remove large pieces of tumor piece meal. Most of the superficial tumor was avascular and did not bleed but as we continued debulking into less necrotic tumor mild bleeding occurred and was treated with cold saline flushes. After extensive debulking we were able to advance the bronchoscope into the lingula were some purulent secretions were seen and performed mini BAL. The tumor however extended into the subsegments of the lingula and deemed likely not salvageable with endobronchial treatment alone.  APC was then used to coagulate the residual superficial layer of oozing tumor. At the end of the procedure distal left mainstem was only 15% obstructed. The left upper lobe proper (anterior and apical posterior segments) were completely patent. The lingula was 80% obstructed and the left lower lobe remained completely obstructed with distal tumor. Once we were satisfied that there was no active bleeding the rigid bronchoscope was removed and the procedure was completed. 
Recommendations:
Transfer to PACU and then home once discharge criteria met. 
Will discuss with oncology if biopsy samples obtained during procedure need any specific mutational analysis. 
Defer to oncology regarding medical and radiation treatment. 
Will monitor for symptoms or radiographic signs of tumor regrowth and possible need for repeat debulking to salvage left upper lobe.

Preoperative Diagnosis:
Lung cancer.
Postoperative Diagnosis:
Lung cancer with malignant airway obstruction.
Procedure Performed:
	Therapeutic bronchoscopy with tumor cryoextraction, APC, and airway dilation.
	EBUS-guided transbronchial needle aspiration (TBNA).
	Balloon dilation and stent placement in the right lower lobe (RLL).
Indications:
1.	Lung cancer progression requiring repeat tissue sampling for molecular analysis.
2.	Malignant airway obstruction.
Consent:
Obtained from the patient after discussing the procedure, risks, and alternatives.
Sedation:
General anesthesia with an 8.5 mm endotracheal tube (ETT).
Description of Procedure:
The procedure was performed in the main operating room. The patient was positioned supine and underwent general anesthesia with an 8.5 mm ETT. Using the Olympus Q190 standard video-bronchoscope, the trachea was inspected and appeared clear. The left bronchial tree was visualized and found to be normal.
The right mainstem bronchus was clear, while the right upper lobe exhibited submucosal tumor growth with patent airways. The proximal bronchus intermedius (BI) displayed normal luminal structure with approximately 15% obstruction from extraluminal tumor. The distal BI was normal. The right middle lobe (RML) had 80% obstruction due to submucosal infiltration. The right lower lobe (RLL) was completely obstructed by endobronchial tumor.
The bronchoscope was exchanged for an EBUS scope. A 2.5 cm lymph node in station 11R1 was id[REDACTED] and biopsied using a 22G ViziShot-2 needle. Five passes were performed, and rapid on-site evaluation (ROSE) confirmed malignancy.
The procedure was then switched to a therapeutic bronchoscope (3.2 mm working channel). Forceps biopsies were taken from the proximal RLL, followed by tumor cryoextraction and ablation with argon plasma coagulation (APC). A Fogarty balloon catheter was used to remove distal tumor and debris. Airway dilation of the RLL was performed with an [REDACTED] mm Elation balloon dilator.
The RLL superior segment remained near-completely obstructed, but visualization revealed mostly uninvolved basilar segments with minimal tumor involvement. A 10 x 15 mm Aero stent was placed in the RLL, with the proximal edge positioned just distal to the RML and jailing the superior segment. The basilar segments were patent beyond the stent. The stent was further dilated using a [REDACTED] mm Elation balloon. Post-procedure, the RLL was approximately 85% patent.
The procedure concluded without complications. The patient was extubated in the operating room and transferred to the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU).
Complications:
None.
Estimated Blood Loss:
Minimal.
Recommendations:
1.	Transfer to PACU for post-procedural monitoring.
2.	Return to inpatient service when appropriate.
3.	Await pathology results for NGS and PD-L1 analysis.
4.	Notify the oncology team at UCSD of the findings and procedural outcomes.

PROCEDURE PERFORMED:  Flexible bronchoscopy with electromagnetic navigation under flouroscopic and EBUS guidance with isocyanate green dye injection for surgical resection.
INDICATIONS FOR EXAMINATION:   pulmonary nodules requiring surgical resection
SEDATION: General Anesthesia
FINDINGS: Following intravenous medications as per the record the patient was intubated with an 8. 5 ET tube by anesthesia. The T190 video bronchoscope was then introduced through the endotracheal tube and advanced to the tracheobronchial tree. The trachea was of normal caliber. The carina was sharp. The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level. Bronchial mucosa and anatomy were normal; there are no endobronchial lesions. The super-dimension navigational catheter was inserted through the T190 therapeutic bronchoscope and advanced into the airway. Using the navigational map created preprocedurally we advanced the 180 degree edge catheter into the proximity of the right upper lobe nodule. Radial probe was used to attempt to confirm presence within the lesion.  A super dimension needle was then inserted through the bronchoscope and 0.75 milliliters of isocyanate Green were injected just below the pleura adjacent to the nodule for planned robotic surgical resection immediately following. The bronchoscope was removed and the procedure was turned over to cardiothoracic surgery. 
ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS:   less than 5 cc 
COMPLICATIONS: None
IMPRESSION:  
- Successful navigational bronchoscopy with ICG marking of right upper lobe peripheral pulmonary nodule
